newsitem.title: USA: IBM wins info management pact from DuPont.
newsitem.headline: IBM wins info management pact from DuPont.

text.p: International Business Machines Corp, continuing its push into the oil and chemical industries, said Monday it had won a contract to take charge of DuPont Co's global business management system.

Noting DuPont was lured away from its existing providers by IBM's competitive bidding and the 'one-stop-shopping' IBM could offer, the company said be it will be charged with both hardware and database software in the DuPont system.
Previously, Hewlett-Packward Co had provided DuPont with hardware, and Oracle provided database software.

IBM said the system will be used for production scheduling, inventory control, customer information, and other functions across DuPon't operations, which span the Americas, the Asia-Pacific region, Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

The system will include IBM's RS/6000 workstations and DB2 database software, which will be installed to run the SAP R/3 enterprise resource planning software made by Germany's SAP AG, the world's largest maker of software used on personal computer networks for corporate operations planning.
IBM said the contract was won by its Process and Petroleum Industry Solutions unit.
